abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Yemen Northern Regional Agricultural
            Development Project. The main objectives of the project
            were: (i) to increase agricultural productivity and incomes
            of farmers by means of (a) improved agricultural services,
            (b) better management of land and water resources and
            manpower and (c) improved irrigation and agricultural
            practices; and (ii) to improve the health and nutrition
            standards of rural families through provision of development
            opportunities for rural women. Bank's performance was
            satisfactory. Borrower's performance was satisfactory.
            The key lessons learned were as follows: (i) for a
            realistic, relevant and practical design and implementation
            of a regional agricultural development project, a full and
            active national participation in the entire project cycle is
            essential; (ii) to improve the effectiveness of project
            management, the Project Preparation Facility (PPF) should be
            fully utilized in briefing project management at an earlier
            stage of implementation on the World Bank (WB) procurement
            procedures and approach; (iii) effective management of
            projects that include major institution building and
            specific socio-economic objectives, necessitates the
            development and application of qualitative indicators to
            assess achievement of these objectives, rather than relying
            solely on delivery of project inputs; (iv) an effective
            monitoring and evaluation system that incorporates
            environmental protection and natural resource conservation
            indicators; (v)extension can only be successful if it can
            offer sound technical support to farmers; (vi) the strong
            social issues concerning the role of women in rural
            development in the Northern Region calls for the adoption of
            a modest and slow approach over a long time frame; and (vii)
            design of projects to be implemented in areas of particular
            difficulty should be simplified to the full extent possible,
            and, where feasible, sites and activities should be grouped
            in order to facilitate implementation and supervision.
